line: (imitating ET) I'll be right here...I love this movie. (pause) This won the Oscar didn't it?
Dawson turns off the movie and switches it to the local news, which his mom co-anchors for.
Ghandi. Spielberg was robbed. This was before he outgrew his Peter Pan syndrome.
(frowning) But Ghandi? I mean why give an Oscar to a movie you can't even sit through?
Thank you.
Joey watches the TV as she gets up to put on her shoes.
New do?
Yeah. She likes big hair.
Must weigh a lot. How does she walk upright?
Dawson laughs then notices Joey putting on her shoes.
Where are you going?
Home.
Spend the night.
I can't.
Come on you always spend the night.
Not tonight.
Why not?
I just don't think it's a good idea for me to sleep over anymore, you know?
Dawson sits up and puts the remote control on his desk.
No, I don't know. C'mon, You've been sleeping over since you were seven. It's Saturday night.
Things change Dawson. Evolve.
What are you talking about?
Joey puts on her jean jacket.
Sleeping in the same bed was fine when we were kids, but we're fifteen now.
Yeah.
We start high school Monday?
Yeah.
Joey taps her chest.
And I have breasts!
(surprised) What?!
She points to Dawson.
And you have genitalia!
I've always had genitalia.
But there's more of it.
Dawson is embarrassed but tries to play it off.
How do you know?
Long fingers...I gotta go.
She moves toward the open window to leave. Dawson reaches out to her.
Whoa Jo, don't hit and run. (Joey turns around) C'mon, explain yourself.
I just think our emerging hormones are destined to alter our relationship and I'm trying to limit the fallout.
Dawson gets up off the bed with his arms crossed, smiling.
Your emerging hormones aren't developing a thang for me, are they?
A thing?
Touches her forehead sarcastically like she has to think about it.
No, I'm not getting a thing for you Dawson. I've known you too long. I've seen you burp, barf, pick your nose, scratch your butt. I don't think I'm getting a thing for you.
So what's the problem?
We're changing and we have to adjust or else the male/female thing will get in the way.
Dawson sits back down on the bed.
What's with this When Harry met 80's crap. It doesn't apply to us, we transcend it.
And how do we do that?
(lying back) By going to sleep. I'm tired.
That's avoidance.
No, it's proof. Proof that we can still remain friends, despite any mounting sexual theoretics.
(pauses for a minute) I don't think it works that way Dawson.
Come on, don't get female on me Joey. I don't want to have to start calling you Josephine.
(smiling) Josephine this!
She leaps onto the bed and attacks him with punches. They tickle and punch each other until Dawson has the upper hand.
(noticing Dawson's body slightly on top of hers) Okay, I give...I give.
We're friends okay? (Joey nods, smiling) No matter how much body hair we acquire? Deal?
Deal.
(leaning back) All right...and we don't ever talk about this again, deal?
Joey smiles.
You got it.
Okay, cool.
Cool.
Dawson and Joey each climb under the covers.
Goodnight Joey.
(snuggling into pillow) Goodnight Dawson.

Joey shifts farther away from Dawson. Dawson looks over, noticing. He moves a little to his side of the bed and glances over again, as she scoots closer to the edge. Dawson pauses, staring up at the ceiling.
Why'd you have to bring this up anyway?
Opening Credits. Paula Cole's "I Don't Want to Wait" plays.

Sail boats drift along a lake on a sunny day. Pan from boats to dock, where Joey is sitting in a lawn chair. The camera moves closer as tense music plays. Suddenly something rises from the lake and grabs her.
Ahhhhhhhh!!
The thing takes her and the lawn chair crashing into the water. Cut to Dawson with his video camera on a hand-made moving crane.
No! Cut, cut, cut. Pacey...three counts you gotta wait before you come up, come on!
We realize it's Pacey cloaked in a sea creature costume. He tries to climb up on the dock but Joey grabs him and pulls him back down.
(climbing up) God, Pacey!
Pacey takes off his sea creature mask and follows her up.
What was that all about?
(watching, and commenting the whole time) Joey...(pause) Pacey, C'mon. You go before she's established on the dock, it's not scary.
Joey grabs a towel and wraps it around her neck.
You did it again, you grabbed my ass.
(waving it off) Like you even have one.
Guys, were way behind schedule, all right. We got two weeks, I'm not going to make the festival.
I'm not playing the victim.
Hello, some cooperation.
Hey, it's Meryl Streep's fault okay, I'm doing my best.
(glaring at him) Bite me.
Dawson notices a yellow taxi pull up next door. A beautiful blond girl steps out and looks around. Pacey glances over and sees the taxi also. Joey is to busy glaring at Pacey to notice.
Well, my mouth drops.
Pacey starts down the dock toward the girl. Dawson pauses, then follows. Joey watches and trails behind them. Cut to the girl walking toward them.
Hi there.
Hi, Pacey. Nice to meet you.
They shake hands.
Hi.
Dawson also shakes Jen's hand.
Hi, I'm Da...
(interrupting) Your Dawson. Dawson, yeah I know. We've met before. I'm Jen.
Oh, the granddaughter from New York, okay.
Joey watches Dawson's face, irked.
That's right
Wow, you look...different.
(turning away from Dawson) Puberty. (shaking Jen's hand) I'm Joey. I live down the creek and we've never met...ever.
So, Jen are you just visiting?
Oh yeah, my grandfather's aorta collapsed and they had to replace it with this plastic tube, so my parents sent me to help for a while.
So you'll be going to school here then?
Uh yeah, tenth grade.
(smiling) Cool, us too.
Cut to Joey who fakes a smile then lets it fade.
Yeah.
Oh good, um look my Grams is waiting. I should go. But it was really nice to meet you guys and I'll see you in school.
If not sooner.
Pacey watches and laughs.
(mimicking) If not sooner.
She turns and walks back down the dock.
(elbowing Dawson) Nice.
Cut to Jen walking away. She glances back at them. Dawson watches her, grinning.
Pacey and Dawson walk through Dawson's front yard. The sea creature costume hangs to dry on a lawn chair.
You think she's a virgin? Wanna nail her?
(laughing) We just met!
They climb the porch steps.
And a wasted moment it was. I mean greater men would be nailing right now, you know what I mean?
(opening front door) Tact, look it up.

They walk into the house to be confronted with the sound of glass breaking. Worried, they walk quickly through the house and into the living room. They see Dawson's parents kissing passionately on a broken coffee table, their clothes in disarray.
Oh God...Mom!
They break their kiss.
Oh, hi son.
He dumps Mrs. Leery on the floor.
Your mother and I were...
(fixing her unbuttoned blouse) uh, just discussing whether or not...
(interrupting) we needed a new coffee table.
Mrs. Leery laughs.
Hi Pacey.
Hi Mr. Leery...Mrs. Leery.
(smiling) Hi Pacey. (noticing Dawson's increasing embarrassment) Oh don't look so red Dawson. It could be worse.
Dawson runs his hands through his hair and looks away.
You know what Mrs. Leery? I really do love that new hairdo.
(fluffing her hair) Oh...Thank you Pacey.
I thought you had to work.
We ran late.
Mrs. Leery (getting up) I should get going. Okay Mr. Man-meat, I'll see you later.
They kiss.
Mom...ah!

The creek. Dogs bark in the background. Joey rows her boat up to their dock and ties it up. She gets out and waltzes up to the house. She's intercepted by her sister's boyfriend, Bodie. He walks towards her with a pot and an apron tied around his waist.
Just the victim I'm looking for.
(smiling) No, Bodie. Not again.
But I'm being tested on this one. Here have a taste.
He gives her a spoonful.
(pauses) Orgasmic. Where's Bess?
Joey's pregnant older sister comes out the front door carrying a shirt.
If you want to wear my things, fine. They're fairly useless to me now. But that means you put them back...where you found them. Got it?
(with attitude) Got it.
I am way too pregnant to be digging underneath your bed.
(even more attitude) So stay out of my room, got it?
She walks away. Bess turns toward Bodie.
I'm going to knock her silly, I swear it.
Here, taste this.
He gives her a sample. She's doubtful at first. That changes, as she tastes it.
(closing her eyes) Mmmm...Orgasmic.
(giving her a kiss) Awww...
Cut to Video Rental Storefront. We see a sign that reads ScreenPlay Video, Movie rentals, New releases and more. Inside Dawson is helping a customer.
(taking videos from man) Thank you.
The customer leaves as Pacey walks in from the back of the store.
So, if your dad's Mr. Man-meat, does that make you Mr. Man-meat Jr. or Mr. Man-meat the second?
They're going to have to drag the creek to find your body, Pacey.
A blond curly headed girl in a black halter-top walks up to them carrying two videos.
Does Forrest Gump go in the comedy or drama section?
How many times are you going to ask that?
It goes in the drama section.
(pointedly) Thank you Dawson.
She walks away to put the video in its place.
(mumbling to Dawson) Can you say wet brain?
Nellie whips around.
I'm sorry what did you say? Did you toss a negative, disparaging remark my way? Because if you did, and correct me if I'm wrong, I'd like to remind you who you are.
I know, I know. Your dad owns the place.
Nooo, I'm talking about in the huge, rotating world of life.
(amused) And who am I Nellie?
Dawson heads toward the back.

Nobody. That's the point. You're not there, you don't even exist. Because if you did, I might have to respond to your pathetic little under the breath one-liners. But instead I take comfort knowing your vapor. Phooo, Phoooo!
She waves her arms around in the air and heads to the back room, where Dawson emerges from, smiling.
Non-existent, nothing.
An attractive older woman in a very short dress walks through the door. The boys stare at her as she approaches them.
Oh my God, look at her!
Have some respect man, she's somebody's mother.
I have it on pretty good authority that mother's have excellent s*x lives, alright.
She reaches the boys.
(smiling) Good afternoon, can we help you?
Yes you can. This is my first time here and I'd like to rent a video.
Excellent. You just fill this out and sh**t us over a credit card.
He bumps Dawson out of the way and hands Tamara an application. Tamara reaches into her purse and passes him her credit card. Dawson heads into the back again.
Thanks...You new in town, because I haven't seen you in here before.
Yes, I am. My name's Tamara, what's yours?
Pacey, nice to meet you.
(handing him back the application) Well here you go Pacey.
Thanks. Um, do you think I could help you locate a video this afternoon?
Maybe. I'm in the mood for romance.
Um, we keep the new releases against the...
(interrupting) Oh no, I'm vintage. (smiling) All the way.
The classics are in the...
(Interrupting again) Where would I find The Graduate?
Cut to Dawson, leaning out from the video stacks in the back.
(flustered) The Graduate is the one...
(interrupting for the third time) Where the older woman, Anne Bancroft, seduces the younger man, Dustin Hoffman?
I'll check in the...
Dawson walks up to the counter, video in hand.
It's right here. Is there anything else I can help you with?
Oh no, that should do it. How much?
Pay when you return.
She turns to leave.
Don't forget your credit card.
(handing it to her) ah...right here.
Enjoy the film.
I will. It was nice to meet you Pacey.
Oh yeah.
She saunters out.
(laughing) Wipe the drool dude.
She was flirting with me!
She was laughing at you.
No, she wanted me!
She wanted Dustin Hoffman.
Close up on Pacey.
He stares after her.
Sunset. Dawson runs towards his house with three videos in his hand. He stops when he spots Jen sitting on the dock, alone. He pauses, then walks over and sits down.
Hey. How's your granddad?
Well, he's breathing. Good sign.
Dawson laughs.
(scratching chin) It's my Grandma that presents a challenge. She has this praying mentality, which is really awkward, since I don't do that whole God thing.
She notices the videos.
Whatcha got here? Let me see. (she grabs them one by one) Creature from the Black Lagoon, Humanoids from the Deep, Swamp Thing?
It's research. I'm making a movie.
Really? Kinda young to be so ambitious.
Fifteen. Spielburg started on a eight millimeter when he was thirteen.
Why movies? What's the attraction there?
I reject reality.
(looking away, a little surprised but laughing) Oh!
Would you like to see my studio?
Cut to a door opening. Dawson and Jen appear and enter Dawson's room.
Hmmm. Long shot here... ahhh...Spielberg fan?
Pretty much worship the man in a God-like way, yeah.
How revealing.

I have his career chronicled up on my wall. If you notice, everything is arranged in receding box office order. Starting with the blockbusters: Jurassic Park, ET, Jaws, Indiana Jones and if you follow it to my critically acclaimed wall...
He walks over to his closet doors and set's the videos on his desk.
(pointing out) I have Schindler's List and The Color Purple. Oh, and for humility purposes I also keep his others.
Dawson opens his closet doors to reveal two posters. Jen laughs.
1941 and Always. In limited but excessible view.
Are you familiar with obsessive reality disorder?

It's beyond that. See I believe that all of the mysteries of the Universe, all of life's questions, can be found in a Spielberg movie. (He sees Jen's doubtful expression) It's a theory I've been working on. See, whenever I have a problem all I have to do is look to the right Spielberg film and the answers revealed.
Have you considered a twelve-step program?
(laughing) Wit. We like that around here.
Cut to Joey walking through Dawson's yard toward the ladder set up against his window. She starts to climb, but pauses at the top when she hears voices.
(off camera) You are very smooth.
Cut back to Dawson sitting on his bed.
In all seriousness, the Boston Film Critics have a program for junior filmmakers. Deadlines in two months. Were really under the g*n.
(off camera) Jennifer!
Jen looks up and goes to a window, near the one with Joey. She leans out and sees her Grams waiting for her, as Dawson looks on. Joey presses against the ladder so Jen won't see her.
I better go...I don't want her to erupt.
I'll see you at school.
(leaving) Bye.
Bye.
Cut to Joey's face as she waits for Jen to leave, then slowly pulls herself through the window.
(noticing) Joey! Hey where you been? Come on, sit down. Watch this.
She picks something off his desk and plops down on his bed, playing with it. Dawson turns on a video of mom's newscast.
(on-screen) 772-5982. Back to you, Bob.
Do you think my mom's sleeping with her co-anchor?
(puzzled) Where did that come from?
Watch.
He rewinds the tape and plays it again.
Something about her B's. They're too soft. (pointing with the remote) Back to you...Bob.
Your reaching. I mean why would your mom be sleeping with her co- anchor. Your dad's the perfect male specimen.
I don't know, but I think they are.
Your just looking for conflict. Everything's a potential script to you. Accept your perfect life Dawson. It's reality.
Close up on Dawson's face as he rewinds it and plays it again, three times.
Jen's Grandparent's house. Jen walks into her grandfather's room where he's sleeping. She looks both ways in the hall before sitting down.
Good morning Granddad.
She looks at his scar, visible under his pajamas. She touches it lightly.
(walking in) What are you doing?
Oh, Oh I was just saying good morning.
Your breakfast is ready.
Oh (pause) I'm glad to be here Grams.
Don't wanna be late your first day.
She walks out of the room leaving Jen holding her Grandfather's hand.
Close up on a pan of scrambled eggs being stirred. Pull back to reveal Jen at the breakfast table.
You know I don't usually eat in the morning Grams. I mean I appreciate the thought and all but my eyes are barely propped open by noon. Just a coffee fix and I'm set.
She pours herself a cup.
(setting a plate in front of her) Well I'll remember that in the future.
(holding the mug) So tell me about this Dawson guy next door. He looks so different. He used to be kinda short and compact.
You stay away, that boy is trouble.
Aren't they all? (pauses) Well, what about the girl who lives down the creek...Joey I think her name is?
(sitting down) That girl from down the creek has been crawling into the window of that boy next door for the past ten years. Neither goes to church, I believe they're what you call the wrong element.
(sipping her coffee) Right.
Grams lowers her head to say prayers. Jen sets her coffee down and lays her napkin in her lap. Grams looks at her out of the corner of her eye.
Say grace dear.
That's okay, you do it.
It would be nice if you did it.
I don't think so Grams. Thanks for the offer.
Is their some reason you don't want to thank our Lord this morning?
You know Grams, I really didn't want to get into this, you know. Kinda causes a headache but um, (pauses) I don't really do well with church and the Bible and this prayer stuff.
Beg your pardon?
I don't covet a religious God, Grams. I'm an Atheist.
Camera lingers on Grams shocked expression. "Tubthumping" by Chumbawumba plays.

Flash scenes of Capeside High School. Kids getting off their bus, tossing footballs and Frisbees. Cut to school hall. Pan down to Jen, at her locker, putting things in her backpack. She holds her schedule in her teeth while trying to fit things in. Nellie walks up.
(smiling) Hi, I'm Nellie Olsen.
(removing schedule from her mouth) Nellie as in Little House...
I know, I know. Little House on the Prairie, it was like my mom and dad's favorite show. But no preconceptions okay? I'm not like her at all.
Uh, I'm Jen.
From New York. I know. How's your grandfather? He has us all worried. He's still on the prayer list at church, you party?
Excuse me?
Par-ty?
Uh, party as in do I like to have a good time, or party as in drink and use drugs?
It's objective.
I like to have a good time. Substance free.
Maybe we should call you Nellie. (shrugs) See ya!
She walks away. Jen turns, a little dazed, back to her locker.
(walking up) Hey! How's it going?
I could really use a cigarette.
(surprised) You smoke?
Uh, I quit. I'm just a little tense.
(smiling) Well you're hiding it well.
I have a great denial system.
Yeah, it's the first day, we're all a little tense. It'll get easier.
Good.
How's your schedule? They screwed up mine.
Jen brings her schedule out and they look it over.
Who do you have first period?
Um...Briston. Biology.
I was just heading that way.
(Smiling) Were you?
She closes her locker and they walk off down the hall. "Tubthumping" plays.

Cut to Pacey in a classroom. He balances a book on his head as other student enter, talking and take their seats. The door opens and Tamara enters. Pacey turns in time to see her, surprised. He grabs the book from off his head.
Tamara.
(smiling) Hello Pacey. Tell you what, why don't you call me Ms. Jacobs during school hours?
Right of course.
(taking the seat next to her) Hey, I was hoping we'd have a class together.
(smiling fakely, she taps her fingers on the table) Here we are.
Cut to Dawson opening the door of a classroom. A TV set plays Psycho. Dawson watches as he walks up to the teacher at the front of the room.
Psycho.
The teacher, startled, turns around.
(pushing pause on the remote) You know the film?
Anthony Perkins, Janet Leigh, Universal, 1960. Little known fact: Did you know that Hitchcock surprised Janet Leigh with freezing cold water in order to get her to scream so effectively?
Who are you?
Dawson Leery.
Then I take it you'll be in my fifth period film lab.
Actually that's why I'm here. (he pulls his schedule out from backpack) There seems to have been some confusion with my schedule. I was denied admittance to your film class.
Then you must be a sophomore.
(pausing) And that's not a good thing?
It's a very popular class Dawson. Seating is limited. Theirs a waiting list, priority goes to upperclassmen.
Well that's stupid.
Excuse me?
Who made that rule?
I did.
Oh.
Why are you so adamant?
(smiling) Passion, Mr. Gold. Pure, mad-driven passion. Movies are my life.
(getting up to sit at desk) Oh I see.

I'm sorry. I'm not coming across well at all here. The point is I'm going to be a filmmaker. It's my life's ambition. It always has been. How many students do you have in this class that can say that?
Cut to Mr. Gold's face.
(continuing) This is a small town Mr. Gold. Theirs not a lot of opportunity for me. You have the power. You could easily override this bizarre rule that denies students their education.

Your very convincing Dawson Leery. But I'm afraid the class is maxed out. I wish I could make case by case exceptions but that would be unfair and problematic. I'm sorry to say that no is my definitive answer.
But...
No, Period. It's a complete sentence.
Cut to Dawson's face. A bell rings. Joey and Jen walk out of Biology into the already crowded hall.
Hey Joey. Um, can I ask you something kinda up front?
Sure.
Are you and Dawson (laughs nervously) a thing?
(shrugging it off) No, were just friends.
Like were going to be, I hope. (pause) You know, my Grams warned me about you. She said you're severely troubled.
Well, no offense but your Gram's is cracked.
Why does she rag on you?
Pick a topic. There's my dad, the imprisoned convict or my sister impregnated by her black boyfriend.
Your father's in prison?
(kinda proudly) Conspiracy to traffic marijuana in excess of ten thousand pounds.
Wow, so then um where's your mother?
(looking away) Oh, she had this cancer thing. It got her.
So then you live with your sister?
And the black boyfriend. (pause) He likes you, you know.
(confused) Who the black boyfriend?
(interrupting) Dawson. Don't abuse his feelings.
Joey walks away. Jen stares after her and sighs.
Capeside cafeteria. A balding, overweight man walks past Dawson, Jen and Joey at a lunch table.
Okay, the bald man, Mr. Herman. He teaches a timid calculus class and packs a .45 magnum. Last year opened fire and took out two students and a custodian.
Pled justifiable homicide. They didn't have a hall pass.
The two laugh. Joey watches them.
Woman in funky black dress. Periodic drinker. Blacks out after two glasses of cheap whine and runs through town with her dress over her head.
Singing Neil Diamond songs.
They share another laugh. Joey is disgusted.
You're good. I should bring you in to touch up my dialogue.
(handing him her script) Um, we're supposed to be working Dawson.
He takes it from her.
Yeah, um would you mind taking a look at Act Three. I'm having a climax issue.
(picking it up) Sure.
Joey sets her hand in her chin and rolls her eyes.
Cut to Tamara eating lunch at her desk. Pacey walks in with his backpack.
Tamara...(correcting himself) I mean, Ms. Jacobs. How was The Graduate?
Just as I remembered.
Are you looking for romance tonight?
(smiling) Why, you got any suggestions?
Uh, have you ever seen The Summer of '42?
(leaning back in her chair) Refresh my memory.
Well, it's about a beautiful woman who seduces a young boy on the verge of manhood.
It's a favorite.
I, uh, could reserve it for you if you like?
Actually, tonight I'm going to see that new film playing at The Realto.
Students start to enter and take their seats. Pacey looks disappointed.
Yeah.
It's getting great reviews.
(brightening) Uh yeah. I guess I'll maybe check it out then.
He walks backwards into a student.
Hey, watch it!
Pacey waves goodbye and heads out. Tamara watches him, thoughtful. A bell rings.
Pacey and Dawson walk down a hall. Pacey puts his arm around Dawson's shoulder.
Hey man. Video woman is my new English teacher. Okay, you, me, the movies tonight. We are stalking a faculty member.
Dude, negative.
What?! I actually have the possibility of losing my virginity in a high level fantasy fashion.
(stopping at a water fountain) Pacey, go home. Walk your dog. It's not going to happen.
Not tonight! That's not the plan, man. I just want to familiarize her with the gaze, the smile, the charming features, you know.
Don't do this to yourself!
Look, it is a fact that a large percentage of older women are attracted to young boys on the verge of manhood. It keeps them feeling young. I read that in Cosmopolitan.
What are you doing reading Cosmopolitan?
Look, I have three menstrually diverse sisters, Cosmo is my savior.
(laughing) What do you need me for?
Moral support. Okay, It'll be cool. You can invite Ms. Teen New York.
He looks down the hall as he talks and sees Jen conversing with a boy in a letterman's jacket. Dawson notices also.
(talking to the boy) That sounds good.
Unless somebody's beaten you to it. C'mon man, get in there. Be assertive. Talk to her alright? You should be the one reading Cosmo. It'll build your female esteem. (pushes him) Go on...
Dawson punches him jokingly and walks down the hall towards Jen. He looks back as he passes the boy and reached Jen.
Dawson, hey, how's it going?
Pretty good. I see you've met Roger Fullford.
They begin to walk.
Yeah, nice guy.
Yeah (pause) Jock quarterback by day, schizophrenic tr*nsv*stite by night.
(laughing) Oh really.
Has what you call a Tori Spelling complex. He's partial to Victoria's Secret.
But can he run in pumps?
They snicker.
Hey, uh Pacey and his crew's directing a trip to the movies tonight, nothing big, just a few of us. Would you like to come?
Jen smiles as the camera pans over them.
Cut to Joey waking home along the boardwalk. Dawson rides up on his bike, a backwards cap on.
Hey Joey! I need a favor.
He gets off his bike and walks it besides her.
(smiling) Uh, oh.
I have a semi-quasi date with Jen tonight, were going to the movies with Pacey and I need you come with us.
(dead panning) I'd rather go down in a plane crash.
C'mon it's going to really, really weird with just two guys and Jen. It'll even it out.
So, would it be like a double date?
Sorta, but not really. Pacey's on this hormonal mission...
(interrupting) Are you having an aneurysm? No way!
It's not like a date-date. It's just so that Jen won't feel uncomfortable.
We wouldn't want that.
C'mon, Joey please? Please, please, please, please, please! (he stops and grabs her arm) C'mon, Joey please?!
(giving in) Whatever.
Thank you! You're the best, I mean it. I know your worried about our relationship and everything but I told you. Nothing has to change. I can tell you anything.
He rides off leaving Joey to continue walking by herself, downhearted.
Jen's grandparent's house.
(off camera) Where exactly are you going?
(walking into kitchen) Well Dawson has a g*n, I thought we'd go knock off a liquor store, then go get tattoos.
Why do you talk like that?
I'm simply trying to establish a rapport with you that's based on humor. I'm completely harmless. You'll see.
Well be back by ten.
(surprised) I can do that. Thanks for being so cool about this. I thought you were going to chain me up to a chair or something.
Not at all, you want to go to the movies, go. Have fun, just as long as you come to church with me on Sunday.
I knew there was going to be catch. Grams, I'm sorry but I'm afraid you're going to have to give up on this one.
I'm afraid I insist.
I'm firm about my beliefs. Please respect them.
I know what happened in New York. Church will do you good.
Let me determine that. Church isn't the answer, not for me. But I promise to you that I'll keep an open mind and honor and respect your beliefs for as long as I'm here.
The decision has been made. You will do what I say, you are under my guard.
(hands on hips) Ah, you know I am trying really hard to keep my rebellious nature in check. (pauses to think) I'll tell you what Grams. I'll go to church when you say the word pen1s.
(startled) You stop that talk!
It's just a word Grams. Clinical and technical. pen1s.
Pause on Grams flustered expression. Jen goes over to her and gives her a hug.
Grams, I really love you, but you have to lighten up. (kisses her on the cheek) I'll see you later.
Dawson's house. Mr. Leery sits on the couch, watching the news as he works. Dawson hops down the stairs.
(running hands through hair) Alright Dad, I'm outta here.
What do you think (he holds up miniature plastic doll) I thought all the waitresses could wear scuba gear.
(massages neck) Completely impractical. Dad, this whole aquatic- themed restaurant idea gets worse on a daily basis.
Shift, your mom's on.
Dawson moves.

Just trust me, alright? It keeps your lips from sticking to your teeth when you smile.
Wait a second. I have to smile? You never said anything about smiling.
(Dawson enters Pacey's dressing room - a closet.)
If you even make one joke about coming out of the closet I swear I...
I can't man. Too obvious. Let me get that.
Tell me the truth Dawson. Do you think I'm a complete fool for doing this?
When did you start considering yourself a public opinion? Pacey, I think you've got testicles of steel for doing this.
Really?
Yeah, here. (throws him a jar of Vaseline)  My mom said to put that on your teeth.
Why?
I have absolutely no idea.
(Cut to onstage.)
And so now ladies and gentlemen here are the contestants in their evening wear. (Some girls walk out in their evening wear.) Thank you, Miss Johnson. And now Miss Josephine Potter.
(Joey walks out. Dawson looks at her, amazed at what he sees.)
(Cut to backstage.)
Could it be Cinderella's fairy godmother did her job a little too well?
(Cut to onstage.)
Thank you Miss Potter.
(Cut to backstage.)
It looks like Prince Charming's found the owner of that glass slipper.
If you have a point I wish you'd get to it.
C'mon Jen. I mean it's pretty obvious your missing the undivided attention of our friend Dawson. Maybe feeling a little dumper's remorse?
You're way off, alright?
Tell me is it the possibility of losing him to someone else that suddenly makes him seem so attractive?
You really think that I am that shallow, huh?
No. I think you're that human.
(Cut to onstage.)
And now Mr. Pacey Whitter.
(Cut to backstage.)
That's me! (He walks out, spins around and takes a bow.
(Pacey is waiting for his interview behind some girls.  His turn comes up.)

I just like to tell my peers that you don't have to be the handsomest guy, you don't have to be the most intelligent guy. You don't even have to be the biggest football stud to be a damn fine Miss WindJammer.
(The audience laughs.)
(Pacey's interview.)

I would tell the world's leaders that a society that chooses w*r and death over the preservation of life can not possibly succeed or thrive. And I guess if that didn't work I'd just tell them I had dirty photos of them, yeah?
(The audience laughs again.)
(Cut to the judge's table.)
So, how am I doing Mrs. Leery?
Pacey! I gotta tell you. You are funny. You're charming. The audience loves you.
Seriously?
You may not have a snowball's chance in hell of winning but you're definitely keeping me from falling asleep.
I'm not even in the running?
Pacey you know these people would rather see this club go down in flames before they would actually crown a male Miss Windjammer.
Yeah but for me to be written off is just completely unfair.
Honey, fair and beauty pageants aren't exactly synonmous.
(Cut to backstage.)
Just think in approximately 2 minutes and 35 seconds this will all be over.
Yeah but I've never had to sing in front of people before. What if I suck?
(gently pushing her) And don't forget to smile!
*Onstage*
Singing "On My Own" from Les Miserables, Miss Josephine Potter.
(Cut to onstage.)
You did an incredible job on Joey. God, it's amazing.
I think we're finally broke into the ranks of being friends. But I miss our friendship, too Dawson.
Me too.
And..and not just our friendship but I guess what I'm trying to say is...
(singing) On my own, pretending he's beside me
All alone, I walk with him til morning.
Without him, I feel his arms around me.
And when I lose my way, I close my eyes, and he has found me.
In the rain,The pavement shines like silver.
All the lights, are misty in the river
In the darkness the trees are full of starlight,
And all I see is him and me forever and forever.
And I know, it's only in my mind,
That I'm talking to myself, And not to him.
And although,I know that he is blind, still I say, there's a way for us.
I love him, but when the night is over.
He's gone, the river's just a river.
Without him, the world around me changes, the trees are bare and everywhere the streets are full of strangers.
I love him, But everyday I'm learning
All my life, I've only been pretending
Without me, his world will go unturning
The world is full of happiness that I have never known.
I love him,I love him,I love him but only on my own.
(Applause from the audience)
Thank you. That was Josephine Potter ladies and gentlemen.
(Cut to backstage.  Dawsons goes to get Pacey.)
Alright Pacey hurry up you're on.
Damn it.
Relax. You're doing great.
I need to know something Dawson. When I asked you if doing this thing was stupid and you made me believe that it had a point...did you ever actually believe that I had a chance at winning this thing?
C'mon Pacey.
That's what I thought. Just another thing for the kids to laugh about Monday morning at school. And who am I to disappoint, right?
Wait, you're not going to do something stupid, are you?
Those people suck! How can I possibly leave here without letting them know that little known fact? I mean, I'm going down I've got nothing to lose.
Wait a minute, Pacey!
Excuse me Dawson. I gotta show to do.
(Cut to onstage.)
Pacey Whitter has changed his program. Instead of a magical act he will perform a dramatic interpretation.
(in a bad rendition of an Irish accent)  Well, I'm not William Wallace. But I am Pacey Whitter.
(from offstage) Pacey Whitter's seven feet tall.

So they say. So they say. And they say that this Pacey Whitter is a dangerous man who slaughters Capeside residents by the dozen with his bare hands. And if he were here he would destroy those who would judge him with sparks from his eyes and wits from his ass.
(Audience laughs.)

(he goes on)  Well I am Pacey Whitter. But who of you are in the position to judge me? Is it you, sir? And what sorts of human beings tolerate being judged? Well judgement stops today. And that which condones me, seems to own me. And I am willing to betray the trappings of my disfunctional life for one chance, just one chance, to stand in front of my fellow countrymen and tell them that you may take my life, but you will never take my freedom!!! Thank you and goodnight.
(Cut to backstage.  Joey passes by a room and overhears some girls talking.)
She won't win but if she does it's because she's a total charity case.
What do you mean?
Oh my god, check it out. She lives in a trailer with her sister who just had an illegitimate baby with her black boyfriend.
(Joey is obviously hurt and turns to leave.  Dawson sees this.)
Dawson, don't try to get me to go back out there. God, I mean, setting myself up like this I am such an idiot.
Joey listen to me. Look, you were phenomenal out there. Don't let these inbred idiots get you down. If you leave now you're never going to forgive yourself.
Look, I don't belong here Dawson. I mean look at me. I mean, how could I have stooped this low for money? I might as well have just sold myself on a street corner.
Joey do you realize you could win this thing? Why do you think they're slamming you? They're terrified of you. They know that you can beat them.
I don't want their money Dawson. I don't want anything from these people. It makes me - -

I don't think its about the money anymore. Joey I know we're not speaking right now, okay? But if we were, I would tell my best friend, who was always afraid to get up in front of class for show-and-tell, how incredibly proud I am of her. How I think she has got more guts and talent and strength of character than all the Hannah Von Winning's in the world put together.
(Cut to Joey onstage.)
For your final question, Miss Potter, please tell us what words of advice you would bestow upon today's youth.

I'd like to tell today's youth that no matter where life takes you, big cities, small towns, you'll inevitably come across small minds. (She glances over the side at the stage where Hannah is watching her.) People who think that they're better than you are. People who think that material things, or being pretty or popular automatically makes you a worth while human being. I'd like to tell today's youth that none of these things matter unless you have strength of character, integrity, sense of pride, and if you're lucky enough to have any one of these things....don't ever sell them. Don't ever sell out. So when you meet a person for the first time, please don't judge them by their station of life, because, who knows, that person just might end up being your best friend. Thank you.
(Applause.)
(The winners are being annonunced.)
And now the exciting moment we've all been waiting for. Our second runner up and two tickets to the Realto for any Tuesday or Thursday matinee is Miss Hannah Von Winning.
(There is applause as Hannah unahppily accepts her award.)
Congratulations. Our first runner up and winner of a free day of beauty at Betty's Hair Barn is Miss Josephine Potter.
(Applause again.  Dawson , Jen, and Pacey are happey for her.)
Congratulations. And the winner of this year's Miss WindJammer is... Miss Roberta Kropp!
(More applause.)
(As the girls walk offstage, Dawson goes up to her.  She flashes her prize and then leaves.  Later Gail and Dason are outside walking and see Joey.)
Joey, honey, you were truly spectacular tonight. You know I voted for you. You should be very proud.
I am.
You kids need a ride home?
No, we'll walk.
Okay, goodnight.
Goodnight, Mom.
Goodnight, honey.
This is the first time in my life that I've been completely speechless.
(Joey smiles.)
What's happening Joey?
I don't know.
(Jen walks up un time to see Dawson take Joey's hand and they sit on a bench.)

I looked at you tonight, and I...and I...it was like you came completely out of your shell. There was like this total new found confidence that just seemed to burst from you. And I know what it must have taken for you to get up and do that tonight. God, look at you.
(Joey laughs nervously.)
(cont.) It's like you transformed into this beautiful goddess.
Dawson...
God, I mean, I'm sitting here with my best friend in the world, and my palms are sweating. I've known you forever, but I feel like I'm seeing you for the first time tonight. Joey? What's wrong?
(Joey smiles, but suddenly stops.)
I don't know, Dawson. There's something that's just not right about this.
Joey I thought this was what you wanted. I mean...
Well, I was wrong. I mean, dressing up, playing the princess. You and I both know this isn't me.
Of course it is.

I thought this was what I wanted. You to see me as beautiful. For you to look at me the way that you look at Jen. But the truth is, I don't want that at all Dawson. I want you to look at me and see the person you've always known and realize that what we have is so much more incredible than some passing physical attraction because you know what Dawson? This is just lipstick. *wipes it off* And this is just hair spray. *takes her hair down* Tomorrow I'm going to wake up, and I'm going to be Joey. Just Joey. The too-tall girl from the wrong side of the creek.
Joey this is all new. We should talk about it. No matter what happens. We can't go back to the way things were.

Dawson, you've had a lifetime to process your feelings for me. And I can't spend the rest of my life hoping that you might throw a general glance in my direction between all the torture-teen romances when every Jen Lindley rolls around.
Joey don't walk away from this.
I have to Dawson.
(Joey leaves Dawson, looking confused.)
(Pacey walks up to Hannah.)
How's it going?
Time to gloat?
No. I've had more experience at being a loser and thought that you might want some pointers seeing that this is your first time.
First time? My brother Matt is on the national tennis team, Caroline's a pediatrician, and Jennifer's a foreign correspondent on CNN, and me, I can't even win a stupid small-town beauty pageant.
It's not like you need the money. Me, on the other hand, I'm stuck living at home, probably for the rest of my life with a bunch of people who think I'm a blight on mankind.
Well aren't we a couple of black sheep? By the way that was a really ballsy thing you did in there tonight.
Thank you. Oh what I wouldn't do to go away for school and be somebody else for awhile.
I've had a total of 23 days at home this year. My last school break, I came home to an empty house. It seems my spring break created a scheduling conflict in my parent's social calendar.
You're kidding.
Roger will probably spend more time in that place than I will.
Who's Roger?
The dog.
Alright.
(Cut to Dawson's house.  Dawson is sitting at the front steps thinking to himself.)
Hi.
So, how'd your day go as a newsman?
Turns out, it's going to be a blip in the 11 o'clock news.

Wow. This may seem like its kind of coming out of the blue but, um, the truth is I haven't thought about much else since Dawson. Look, I know that we didn't really give our relationship a chance, well um, I didn't give it much of a chance. And you're right I didn't really give you a good reason for the break-up and truth is, I don't even know. Is it too late to ask for another chance?
You're kidding.
I couldn't be more serious.
God, Jen.
Uh I guess I got the answer.
It's just that, you know, now's really not the best time. I don't know, I kind of, there's something I need to figure out first.
Okay, well, you know where I am.
How could I forget.
Goodnight Dawson.
Goodnight Jen.
(Cut to Joey's bedroom.  She is listening to "On My Own."  She pulls her hair up and smiles.  Cut to Dawson's room.  He is smiling too...)
Hey!
Hey.
You're here!
Yeah. I thought we were watching movies, Dawson.
Yeah. I'm glad you're here. I just. I didn't think. I didn't even get any movies from the store.
(disappointed) Well, actually, I came by to tell you that I couldn't make it. So.
You dropped by to tell me you couldn't drop by?
Yeah. See you, Dawson.
(Joey begins to walk towards the window.)
Joey, stay. We can watch bad reruns and throw sarcastic remarks at the television.
(walking towards Dawson's bed) Well, for the record, I'm getting pretty tired of television. I mean, the metaphor alone is making me nauseous.
What are you talking about?
I mean, every night, it's the same. We hang out in your Speilbergized bedroom and watch obscure movies and TV reruns, It's so predictable.
(Dawson turns on his TV and starts watching.)
This is a great show.
(Dawson sits down on his bed and Joey puts one knee on the bed.)
It's a huge two-parter with a big cliffhanger.
Cliffhanger? Come on, Dawson, you of all people should know that a cliffhanger is merely a manipulative TV standard designed to improve ratings.
No, a cliffhanger's purpose is to keep people interested and keep them guessing what's going to happen in future episodes.
(Joey sits on the bed and takes the remote control from Dawson.)
Yeah but just like in our own lives, they are so predictable.
(Joey turns the television off and turns to Dawson.)

I mean the producers put the characters in some contrived situation hoping that the audience will think something is going to change. But you know what? It neverdoes. It's back to the same way it was before your so-called cliffhanger. It's boring, Dawson.
Well, what if this time it was different? What if this time in the cliffhanger, something changes? You wouldn't want to miss that, would you?
(Dawson takes the remote control back and turns the TV back on.)
It still sounds like one big tease to me, Dawson.
Dawson's Creek theme song and credits.
(Grams is holding Jen's grandfather's hand and talking to him at his bedside.)

What else? Arthur Elders missed the meeting for the third week in a row. He said his staff meeting ran late but Marisa Parker saw him leave the Happy Hour at the Roman Fryer, which doesn't surprise me one bit. And in addition, your granddaughter and I seem to be co-existing lately.
(Jen appears at the door and listens.)
She broke it off with Dawson Leery though. Heaven help her, just between you and me, I think she's starting to miss him.
(Grams touches his face as Jen goes into the room.)
How's he doing this morning?
Peaceful. No real change. Same sleep he's been in for the past three months.
(Jen goes over to her Gramps and touches his hand)
Well, I'll see you after school.
Okay. Oh, don't forget your sweater. It's going to turn cool this afternoon.
I know. Bye, Gramps.
(Jen touches his hand once more before leaving.)
(slowly) Good-bye Jen.
(Grams rushes to the door.)
Jennifer! Jennifer! He's awake.
(Jen runs back to the room in amazement.)
(Jen and Dawson are at Capeside high walking down the halls.)
I just feel like this giant cloud has been lifted off my shoulders, you know?
(Dawson laughs.)

I mean, they had to take him to the hospital to run some more tests so I can't see him until tomorrow. I don't know. For the first time in a long time, I feel like letting loose and having some fun. I mean, I know it's a school night and everything.
(Dawson turns his locker combination.)
But what do you say? You and me?
Umm. Tonight, actually I have plans with Joey. I guess I could ask her if we could bag.
(Dawson opens his locker to put his books away.)
No, no, whatever.
(Jen sees Joey walking down the hall.)
Speak of the devil.
(Dawson closes his locker and turns around to see Joey.)
Joey!
(Joey stops and turns to see Dawson and Jen.)
Oh, Hey guys.
Is everything okay?
Yeah. I think so. How do you go about getting a passport?
Why? Where are you going?

Mrs. Tringle just informed me that Grace Elkins turned down a scholarship to spend next semester in France because she doesn't want to leave her boyfriend so the faculty had to pick a replacement and...
(Jen and Joey are thrilled at the announcement, but Dawson is somewhat disappointed.)
And they picked you?
Yeah.
Dawson, isn't that amazing?
(Dawson takes a step foward towards Joey.)
Wai..Wait a minute, slow down. You're going to France?
shrugs her shoulders I don't know yet. I mean, I have two days to decide.
If you did go, when would you leave?
Two weeks.
(Joey glances over at Jen.)
Umm, See you guys later.
(Joey leaves the two with Dawson still in a state of shock.)
I definitely think she should go, don't you?
Umm, why not?
(Dawson walks back to his locker, slightly dazed.)
(At the S.S. Icehouse, Bessie is cleaning up one of the tables as Joey is telling her about France.)
I mean,France is so far away.I won't know anybody, I don't speak the language, plus I don't know if I could spend a year in any country that worships Mickey Roark.
Well, whatever you decide to do, I think it's an honor just to be asked. Really, kid, I'm proud of you. Dad will be too when you tell him all about it.
(Bessie piles up a bunch of dirty dishes and starts walking to another table. Joey follows Bessie.)
Uh, question. Why would I tell Dad?
Don't tell me you've forgotten what tomorrow is.
Apparently, I have.
It's his birthday, Joey.
Well, you're on your own Bessie. Enjoy yourself.
I'm not going Joey. You are.
(Bessie walks away from the table and Joey continues to follow her.)
Wake up, Bessie. I am not going anywhere.
Joey, we made a deal. I know you remember alternating birthday visits as long as he's in there. Now, I went last year, so according to my calculations, it's your turn.
Forget it.
You're not getting out of this one. If you don't go, I swear to God, I'll make you regret it.
(Bessie puts the tray of dirty dishes down and turns to face Joey.)
Look, I know you're still angry at him for what he did to Mom and to us, I am too. But you know what, Joey? He's still our father.
Yeah, our father who art in prison.
(Joey walks away.)
(Cut to Pacey who is riding his bike down the street. We hear a police siren as Doug pulls up next to Pacey. Pacey gets off his bike, drops it,  and walks over to the driver's side of the car.)
What do you want, man? I have to go to work.
Dad's looking for you. He's pissed.
Gee, I wonder what it is I did this time?
Well, I'd say it's more like what you didn't do, like pass any of your mid-terms this semester. Principal Igar called to issue the official failure watch and frankly, Dad's a little worried.
Well, you tell him that the concern is appreciated but he should save it for the closet case with the g*n.
(As Pacey walks back to his bike, Doug gets out of his car.)

Tell me something, Pacey. Does being the leading contender for the title of the official joke of Capeside bother you even a little bit? 'Cause I must say it's a distinction the rest of the Witter family would rather live without.
Why don't you just run along and go grab a cat out of a tree or something and tell Dad that if he wants to talk to me he should do it himself.

You know one day, Pacey, you're going to be tired of being a joke and it's going to be too late. You're going to wake up and realize you're just a bad punchline nobody's laughing at. You have a good day now, little brother.
(Doug goes back to his police car and drives off as Pacey takes off on his bike.)
(Cut to Dawson and Joey are purchasing tickets at the Piedmont Coach Lines ticket office. Afterwards, they head towards the railing that looks out to the creek.)
You know, thanks a lot for coming with me, Dawson. I could k*ll Bessie for making me do this.
Not a problem. When was the last time you saw your dad anyway?
Two years ago.
(Joey leans against the railing and turns to face Dawson)
About the same time I discovered he was trafficking marijuana while cheating on my dying mother with a bleached blonde cocktail waitress.
Well, it's only for today.
(Dawson puts his hand on Joey's shoulder)
You'll get through it, I promise.
Thanks.
By the way, any decision on the European thing?
Still waiting out for the fantasy elements.
It's an incredible opportunity.
And what would you do if I left?
Umm.
(Dawson also leans back against the railing and looks at her as he smiles.)
su1c1de. Something painless, you know, pills, car fumes maybe.
No, really Dawson. What would you do?
If Paris made you happy, (pause) then I'd be happy for you.
(A bus pulls up to the prison gate.  Dawson gets off with Joey behind him. They walk around to the other side of the bus and stop for awhile.)
So, Are you ready?
No.
Hang tough.

character: Dawson goes to grab her hand but she tries to pulls away. They walk up to a prison information booth to see the time.  5

line: You're kidding me. We missed visiting hours?
I'm sorry these are the rules. Family visitation ends promptly at 5 o' clock.
Yeah, but we just spend 4 hours on a bus. I mean, what are we supposed to do now?

Look, Miss. I know you think your problem is very important and I'm sure to you, it is, but here at a prison housing over 800 felons it's not even a blimp on the radar. Now can I ask you are we done here yet?
(Joey and Dawson walk away and stop by a fence.)
This is becoming a far bigger nightmare than I ever anticipated.
Look, Joe. I'm sorry, I know you wanted to get this over with. If you ask me really nicely, I'll come back with you tomorrow.
Thanks for the offer Dawson, but there's got to be a better solution then spending another day on the bus.
Maybe there is.
(Joey and Dawson founr the Liveless Motel and spend their night there.  Dawson is watching TV when Joey comes out of the bathroom.  She switches the bathroom light off and walks over to the bed.)
I just got off the phone with my mom and she said she'd tell Bessie we had to stay overnight. Feel like watching some TV?
No thanks, I'm pretty tired. I think I'm just going to hit the sack.
(Dawson gets up from the bed and turns the TV off. They walk to the sides of the bed.)
Okay. So umm are we sleeping left to right?
(Joey takes her jacket off.)
Yeah, as usual is fine with me.
(Dawson begins to unbutton his shirt)
Okay. It's just the first time we've ever slept together in a foreign bed.
Is that a problem, Dawson?
Dawson and Joey both take their shoes off and Joey turns the light off.
No, it's just different, you know? A little weird.
(Dawson and Joey both get into the bed and try to get into a comfortable position.)
And lumpy.
(Joey and Dawson are laying on the backs.  Dawson glances at Joey and then sits up.)
You know maybe I should just sleep on the floor.
(sitting up) You can't sleep on the floor. It's freezing. Besides, what's the big deal Dawson? I mean, we've mean sleeping in the same bed for years.
(laughs nervously) Never mind. Yeah.

Dawson and Joey both lay back down. Joey rolls over on her side with her back facing Dawson. Dawson looks over at her and movevs himself closer to her on his side. He puts his head on his hand and watches her.
Jo?
Yeah?
I don't want this to affect your decision about France but I would really miss you if you left.
Well, I'd miss you too Dawson.
I've been thinking about us a lot lately.
(smiling) You have?
Yeah, I have.
And?
And I have to figure out where we are.nWhat's going on between us.
(Joey rolls over to face him.)
And how do we do that Dawson?
(Dawson looks at her.)

God. I'm sorry Jo I'm not...I'm just not nall there. I mean, I can analyze somebody else until the cows wander home but as soon as I turn all that adult perception on myself, it's like, I completely lose connection between my heart, and my head. It's like the two are incompatible and I can't get it together. And I wish I could because I'm so scared of what may happen if I don't. Does this make any sense to you at all?
What are you so scared of Dawson?
(Joey rolls back over.)
I don't know....I don't know.
(Cut to Jen in the hospital waiting room. Grams enters and Jen gets up from her chair.)
How is he?

Tests seem to be going well. They tell me it was because he was lucky, but I know luck has nothing to do with it. I know it's because of our daily prayer and our faith in the Lord. That's what got him through it.
You know, no one's happier about his recovery than me but I very much doubt prayer had a whole lot to do with it.
Jennifer. God has a hand in all good things.
(Grams walks behind Jen and sits down.)
Oh but he had nothing to do with w*r, famine, AIDS, huh?
It isn't always up to us to understand the Lord's ways.
You know, don't go back to business as usual. Gramps is better. That's all that matters. I guess we'll just enjoy it in our own ways.
(Joey is leaning against one of the prison tables talking to Dawson and waiting for her dad.)
I should probably go now. I'll be right outside.
No, Dawson. You're not going anywhere.
Joey you haven't seen him in forever. Don't you want to spend some time alone with him?
Yeah right. Like I want to spend time alone with the man who's responsible for the destruction of my family.
(Joey's father comes in and takes the seat across from Joey.)
If I knew you were coming I would have sent for cigars and champagne. A couple of donuts anyway. Joey, you're beautiful.
(clenching her teeth) No, I'm not.
Hello, Dawson.
Hello, Mr. Potter.
I thought the other night you might come, but I thought I better not get my hopes up. Birthdays in prison are depressing enough.
Well, I'm here, aren't I?
I'm so glad. You have no idea. You're all grown up. It's amazing.
Well, that's what people do. They grow up.
(Dawson looks down.)
How's...uh...school?
That's what you wanna talk about?
What do you want to talk about?
Nothing.
It gets so lonely here, Joey. I miss you. And your sister. I miss my family.
Your family? Tell me this, do you miss Mom?
Yes, very much. Joey, talk to me. Tell me what you're thinking.
You don't want to know what I'm thinking. Believe me. You know this was a mistake. And I guess I should tell you that I'm probably going to be leaving in a few weeks, I'm going to France.
(Dawson is surprised at her sudden decision.)
So I won't be around anymore. And that family that you miss - doesn't exist anymore. It's over.
(Joey gets up and begins to walk away.)
It's not over Joey. It's still a family.
Well, it's over for me. Happy Birthday, Dad.
(Koey leaves and Dawson gets up, not sure what to do.)
Joey! (he turns back to Mr. Potter) I should go with her. Umm, I'm sorry
Dawson wait please. Tell me about her. Tell me about my daughter.
What do you want to know?
Anything, everything.
She's great.
(Dawson sits back down where Joey was sitting and becomes involved in his own world.)

I mean, she's smart, she's beautiful, she's funny, she's a big ol' scaredy cat. If you creep up from behind her she'll jump out of her skin. It's pretty amusing. She's honest. She always calls them just like she sees them. You can always count on getting the truth from Joey even if the truth hurts. She's stubborn. We fight a lot. She can be so frustrating sometimes. But she's a really, really, good friend. I know her to a fault. She believes in me. And I'm a dreamer so it's so good to have somebody like that in my life. If she goes away, I don't know what I'm going to do. I mean, she's my best friend, you know? She's more than that. She's everything.
(Cut to Dawson and Joey walking down to the end of the pier. Dawson is walking in front of Joey.)
Okay, whats your deal?
What do you mean?
You haven't said one word the entire bus ride home. I mean, if anyone should be brooding it's me. Talk to me Dawson. What did he say?
(Joey grabs Dawson's arm and turns him around.)
He asked a lot of questions about you. He misses you. He loves you. You shouldn't have left.
Don't lecture me.
(Joey walks in front of Dawson and he follows her.)
I'm not, but...

Gail.
... and liars.

What I am saying is for the past two months, the past 62 days, everytime that I've come home late, everytime that I have made an excuse to leave this house, everytime that I haven't been with you, I've been with someone else. Well, have you ever played the "If" game?

Oh, it's a really good way to get to know each other. I ask you a question like, "If you could only eat one food for the rest of your life, what would it be?" And then you answer and ask me something.

It's just a really good way to get to know each other, that's all. Okay, let's see, ummm, if you had to pick one city that you had to live in for the rest of your life, what would it be?

Fears of abandonment turned into fantasy spectacles of security and joy. Frank Capra and Steven Spielberg were often compared for their thematic content.

What I like most about those movies is the fact that no matter how far off the pedestal the character fell they always got a second chance. Forgiveness is one of the greatest gifts the Lord has given us with it comes understanding.

Get ready Mitch, because if you think it can't get worse, it can. My reason is proposterous. I have no reason. No. I woke up one day, Mitch, and I realized, my life was perfect. When everything is just the way you've always wanted it to be? I have the perfect home, a career, the most gifted child, a husband who stimulates me mind, body, and soul everyday of my life. I want for nothing. And I guess that left me feeling empty not wanting. And I just wanted to want again. So, I set out to achieve it, and boy did I succeed. Because what I want now, I want back everything that I've lost. Mitch, I'm so sorry.

Well she's carefully considered all possible scenarios, detailing a god-like source. And she has found them unconvincing. And ,while she respects those who chose to believe in a higher being, she herself does not. Simply put Grams, she grew up.

ok. Thats nice and everything but...

Ya know I really appreciate that effort Dawson but it really is that bad. Ya know what lets be honest it's worse. This is cataclysmic. This is one of those rare mile stone events that separate the first half of your life from everything that follows. Ah, My only consolation is the faint hope that this doesn't reach Tamara. I... I can do that. I can be cool. Casual. A smile, a little wink, and easy stride through the Home Ec. wing, Ya know, like, like nothing happened. Like I got not a care in the world.
Yeah.

Right and you're so sure that you know the difference?
You, you don't know what you're talking about.

Leaving so soon?
Yeah, thought I'd check out the scenery up the coast. My travel agent says the leaves are spectacular this time of year.
I assume you haven't tried to steal anything. Other than my girlfriend.
Hey, relax, alright. You win. I just talked to Jen and apparently she's not as confused as she seems. So, it looks like the nice guy gets the girl after all.
(Billy gets his luggage and leaves, then turns around.)
Oh, by the way, if traffic's with me, I can make it up here from New York in under three and an half hours. You better treat her good,Dawson.
I will.
(Billy leaves.  Dawson looks at the window and sees Jen at the pier.  He goes out to join her.)

(putting his arms around her) You know for someone who views themselves as a tragically nice guy, I spend an awful lot of time apologizing. Jen, I'm sorry about what I said earlier. Insecurity brings out the worst.
(Jen pulls away from him and stands on the other side of the pier.)

You know how you're always curious about how my life was like in New York? Truth is, it's really no different than it is right now. I mean, geography aside, I am still the same stupid girl who's always found it easier to escape into a relationship than to face life on her own.
Jen, that's not true, okay? It's this whole Billy thing. Now that the ghost of boyfriend's past is gone, we can go back.

To what? Dawson, I'm sixteen, I've, I've never stayed home on a Saturday night. I've never gone stag to a school dance. I mean, I'm pretty, I'm lucky, I'm fortunate and I am still way too unhappy most of the time. I told Billy today that it was over with us.
I know. He told me
And now I have to say the same thing to you.
(surprised) What? Jen?

I know I criticize you for living in a fantasy world, Dawson, but the truth is, I envy you. Everything's so new, so untouched for you. i would gladly trade in all my experiences for just an ounce of your idealism. And I wish I knew some better way to say this but.
Yeah, but we can make it work. We can fix this.
No!
I know we can. We can. You know, sleep on this. We'll talk in the morning. We don't need to go over this now.
Dawson, please. Listen to me. I've got to take a few steps back. I've, I've got to try life on my own for awhile.
(upset) You can't just make me fall for you and then bail as soon as. I can't.
I'll miss you, you know.
(Dawson turns around.)
Yeah.

I'll be sleeping 80 feet away from you and it will feel like a thousand miles. I'll regret my decision constantly. I'll kick myself to no end and when I come crawling back to you, you'll have every right to say 'take a hike, Jen, I'm with somebody else now'.

Somebody who appreciates me. Somebody who doesn't blow into town with her dysfunctional past and play mind games with the boy next door. Somebody who is capable of a healthy, committed relationship and unfortunately, somebody nothing like you.

Dawson, Neighbor girl dumped you. No one died. Just get over it.

It's not a matter of time, Dawson, it's a matter of degree. You haven't eaten and you stare at Jen's house like it's going to disappear. And I've seen you at school. You spy. It's twisted. And I'm almost afraid to ask what movie you brought back tonight.
Sid and Nancy.
See, your problem is that you're getting off on this.

*getting up from the window and going to his desk* Sorry, Joey.*Picks up ET doll* It's tough to come up with creative moping strategies once I realized that everything I'm about is exactly what turned her off. It's not like I can learn to dance or get a new haircut or something.
*gets up from the bed and goes over to her* Dawson, she dumped you, not your belief system.

Everything reminds you of her.
Oh?
Dawson, you've known the girl for three months. How could everything possibly remind you of her?
I don't know, Joey, I can't explain it. It just does.

*getting off his car* Hey, just the man I was looking for.

I know the bouncer.
Of course, there's school.

You made your point. And you know what? You're right. This is exactly what I need. To get away from her. To get away from here. You know what, she's going to freak when I'm not there. It'll be good to let her wonder about me for awhile.
*Billy and Dawson drive off together*

Well, Ted's a lucky man.

Oh.

Billy.
Hey. Great so we're ready to go?
Yeah. I'm going to go turn in my math homework and we're out of here.
*Dawson rushes off*
Yeah. Walk on the wild side.

*to Joey* Listen, I heard something this morning that I thought you should. *Jen spots Billy by her locker*
At the risk of sounding redundant, what the hell are you doing here?

Oh?

God.

I'm going to go downstairs and get a drink.
